09b6554b-70aa-4153-8ef3-5427fb375b43.text: This paper explores the limitations of current agent benchmarks and evaluation practices, arguing that they hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. The authors identify several shortcomings, including a narrow focus on accuracy, conflating the needs of model and downstream developers, inadequate holdout sets, and a lack of standardization in evaluation practices. They propose five contributions to address these shortcomings: (1) AI agent evaluations must be cost-controlled, (2) jointly optimizing accuracy and cost can yield better agent design, (3) model developers and downstream developers have distinct benchmarking needs, (4) agent benchmarks enable shortcuts, and (5) agent evaluations lack standardization and reproducibility.

f3008f2a-65cf-43fb-8c6a-041abbdb806f.text: AI agents are becoming an increasingly important research direction, with benchmarks driving their development. The authors present an analysis of current agent benchmarks and evaluation practices, revealing several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. These shortcomings include a narrow focus on accuracy without considering other important metrics like cost, conflating the needs of model and downstream developers, inadequate holdout sets, and a lack of standardization in evaluation practices. The authors propose a framework to address these issues and encourage the development of agents that are truly useful in real-world applications rather than just being accurate on benchmarks.

3e093312-241e-410a-b71d-7a0c37ed271d.text: AI agents are an exciting new research direction, and agent development is driven by benchmarks. Our analysis of current agent benchmarks and evaluation practices reveals several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. First, there is a narrow focus on accuracy without attention to other metrics. As a result, SOTA agents are needlessly complex and costly, and the community has reached mistaken conclusions about the sources of accuracy gains. Our focus on cost in addition to accuracy motivates the new goal of jointly optimizing the two metrics. We design and implement one such optimization, showing its potential to greatly reduce cost while maintaining accuracy. Second, the benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers have been conflated, making it hard to identify which agent would be best suited for a particular application. Third, many agent benchmarks have inadequate holdout sets, and sometimes none at all. This has led to agents that are fragile because they take shortcuts and overfit to the benchmark in various ways. We prescribe a principled framework for avoiding overfitting. Finally, there is a lack of standardization in evaluation practices, leading to a pervasive lack of reproducibility. We hope that the steps we introduce for addressing these shortcomings will spur the development of agents that are useful in the real world and not just accurate on benchmarks.

ce8a6b59-7d25-40f6-8cc3-ff52ec513b90.text: This paper analyzes the current state of AI agent benchmarks and evaluation practices, highlighting several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. It argues that current benchmarks focus too narrowly on accuracy without considering other important metrics, such as cost. This narrow focus leads to mistaken conclusions about the sources of accuracy gains and encourages the development of complex and costly agents that are not truly useful in the real world. The paper proposes a principled framework for addressing these shortcomings and calls for a shift towards more comprehensive and standardized evaluation practices that consider factors beyond accuracy. The authors provide a case study of the WebArena benchmark, demonstrating how the current evaluation practices can lead to misleading results. They also show that many agent benchmarks do not include adequate holdout sets, which allows agents to overfit to the benchmark and take shortcuts. The paper concludes with a call for more rigorous and reproducible agent evaluation practices that take into account the full range of factors that are important for real-world applications.

c048e6b0-925e-4bb0-be6c-2e4e313cac92.text: This paper examines the current state of AI agent evaluation and identifies several shortcomings that limit its usefulness for real-world applications. The authors argue that existing benchmarks often focus narrowly on accuracy without considering other important factors like cost, and this can lead to agents that are complex and costly but perform poorly on tasks outside of the benchmark. They also discuss the importance of standardizing evaluation practices to ensure reproducibility and provide a principled framework for avoiding overfitting. The paper proposes several recommendations for addressing these shortcomings, such as jointly optimizing accuracy and cost, developing separate benchmarks for model evaluation and downstream use, and introducing holdout sets to prevent overfitting.

499667c4-7d21-422b-9769-7fd8d20a8af4.text: This paper analyzes current AI agent benchmarks and evaluation practices, arguing that they hinder their usefulness in real-world applications.  The authors identify five key shortcomings: a narrow focus on accuracy without attention to other metrics, inadequate holdout sets, a conflation of the benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers, a lack of standardization in evaluation practices, and a pervasive lack of reproducibility. They offer a principled framework for addressing these shortcomings and propose a new goal of jointly optimizing cost and accuracy in agent design.  This framework is demonstrated through a case study of the HotPotQA benchmark.  The paper concludes by advocating for a move away from traditional agent benchmarks that allow shortcuts and encourage overfitting.

a83e09ed-a3b7-43a1-99b5-93c97f422699.text: This paper argues that current AI agent benchmarks do not accurately reflect real-world applications and suggests five key contributions to improve their design and evaluation. These contributions are: 1) Agent evaluations must be cost-controlled to avoid over-optimization for accuracy at the expense of practicality. 2) Jointly optimizing accuracy and cost can lead to better agent design. 3) The benchmarking needs of model developers and downstream developers must be recognized and addressed. 4) Agent benchmarks can enable shortcuts, so proper hold-out sets are essential to avoid overfitting. 5) Standardization of evaluation practices is necessary to improve reproducibility and reliability. The paper concludes that these principles are crucial for developing agents that are truly useful in the real world and not just accurate on benchmarks.

b9f2f68b-7b42-4d0a-baf1-6d772c3a245e.text: AI agents are an exciting new research direction, and agent development is driven by benchmarks. Our analysis of current agent benchmarks and evaluation practices reveals several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. First, there is a narrow focus on accuracy without attention to other metrics. As a result, SOTA agents are needlessly complex and costly, and the community has reached mistaken conclusions about the sources of accuracy gains. Our focus on cost in addition to accuracy motivates the new goal of jointly optimizing the two metrics. We design and implement one such optimization, showing its potential to greatly reduce cost while maintaining accuracy. Second, the benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers have been conflated, making it hard to identify which agent would be best suited for a particular application. Third, many agent benchmarks have inadequate holdout sets, and sometimes none at all. This has led to agents that are fragile because they take shortcuts and overfit to the benchmark in various ways. We prescribe a principled framework for avoiding overfitting. Finally, there is a lack of standardization in evaluation practices, leading to a pervasive lack of reproducibility. We hope that the steps we introduce for addressing these shortcomings will spur the development of agents that are useful in the real world and not just accurate on benchmarks.

topics: Joint Optimization of Accuracy and Cost

458ec428-2d2c-4b74-8c66-998e58b38e0f.text: The analysis of current agent benchmarks and evaluation practices reveals several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. Firstly, the paper argues that there is a narrow focus on accuracy without attention to other metrics. The paper suggests a new goal of jointly optimizing both metrics. Secondly, the paper argues that the benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers have been conflated, making it hard to identify which agent would be best suited for a particular application. Thirdly, many agent benchmarks have inadequate holdout sets and sometimes none at all. The paper recommends a principled framework for avoiding overfitting. Finally, the paper argues that there is a lack of standardization in evaluation practices, leading to a pervasive lack of reproducibility. The paper concludes that the shortcomings in the agent benchmarks could be solved by (1) cost-controlled evaluation, (2) jointly optimizing accuracy and cost, (3) distinct benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers, (4) avoiding shortcuts by using proper holdouts and (5) standardized evaluation practices.

3ee0e080-f085-4f6c-af74-153fbb9d36ac.text: This paper analyzes the current state of AI agent benchmarks and evaluation practices, finding several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. These shortcomings include a narrow focus on accuracy without attention to other metrics, conflation of the benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers, inadequate holdout sets, and a lack of standardization in evaluation practices. The authors propose five contributions to address these shortcomings: AI agent evaluations must be cost-controlled, jointly optimizing accuracy and cost can yield better agent design, model developers and downstream developers have distinct benchmarking needs, agent benchmarks enable shortcuts, and agent evaluations lack standardization and reproducibility. The authors hope that these contributions will spur the development of agents that are useful in the real world and not just accurate on benchmarks.

8dd23607-17cd-4db5-b3de-79281b5a5407.text: AI agents are becoming a significant research direction, but existing benchmarks and evaluation practices have several shortcomings that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. First, there is a narrow focus on accuracy without attention to other metrics, leading to SOTA agents that are needlessly complex and costly, and the community has reached mistaken conclusions about the sources of accuracy gains. Second, the benchmarking needs of model and downstream developers have been conflated, making it hard to identify which agent would be best suited for a particular application. Third, many agent benchmarks have inadequate holdout sets, sometimes none at all, leading to agents that take shortcuts and overfit to the benchmark in various ways. Finally, there is a lack of standardization in evaluation practices, leading to a pervasive lack of reproducibility. We hope that the steps we introduce for addressing these shortcomings will spur the development of agents that are useful in the real world and not just accurate on benchmarks.

fd829c6c-f592-4679-b608-1234a97de20d.text: AI agents are a rapidly developing area of research with the potential to revolutionize many aspects of our lives. However, the current evaluation practices for these agents are inadequate and often misleading. The authors argue that the focus on accuracy alone is insufficient, and that cost-control and other metrics like fairness, robustness, and societal impact must be considered. The authors also highlight the shortcomings of current benchmarks, arguing that they often allow for shortcuts and overfitting, which can lead to agents that are brittle and not generalizable to real-world applications. They propose a set of principles for designing better benchmarks and evaluation practices, emphasizing the need for holdout sets, standardized evaluations, and clear reporting of costs. The authors believe that their recommendations will help to spur the development of more robust and useful AI agents.

75a9d1c5-0348-4d2b-93fd-66234999eac7.text: AI agents are becoming an important research direction in the field of Artificial Intelligence. This paper analyses several shortcomings of current agent benchmarks and evaluation practices that hinder their usefulness in real-world applications. The authors argue that a narrow focus on accuracy without considering other metrics like cost, leads to mistaken conclusions about the sources of accuracy gains. They further emphasize the need for jointly optimizing accuracy and cost to ensure the development of agents that are useful in the real world and not just accurate on benchmarks. The paper identifies five key contributions: (1) AI agent evaluations must be cost-controlled. (2) Jointly optimizing accuracy and cost can yield better agent designs. (3) Model developers and downstream developers have distinct benchmarking needs. (4) Agent benchmarks enable shortcuts. (5) Agent evaluations lack standardization and reproducibility.
